course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Structure and Function of Proteins
course.description: Determination of protein sequences and three-dimensional structures; relationship between structure and function; principles of protein design and engineering; molecular, biochemical and genetic approaches to study protein function and regulation.

reviews.author: msi
reviews.title: Take for an easy A
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered:
- Review of Biochemistry I (e.g. protein structures)
- Chemical Modification of Proteins
- Post Translational Modifications
- Protein Purification
- Protein Characterization
- Protein Quantification
- X-ray Crystallography
- Nuclear Magnetic Resonance
- Cryo-EM
- Tools for Determining Protein Structure and Function
-Protein Structure Prediction
- Proteins and Disease

The content is very broad. Since I have barely any previous knowledge on structural biology, I enjoyed getting an overview of many topics. But this will depend on whether you prefer broad or more focused content.

Prof. Dang also did a quiz in the beginning (not graded) to assess our previous knowledge. When explaining certain topics he would focus on things he knew many people got wrong in the quiz.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Dang is known for having a strong accent and it definitely is hard to understand him sometimes. However, he is willing to go over a topic multiple times when needed, and he also is very responsive to emails. He answers any questions you have in depth, so don't be afraid to reach out.
reviews.comment_grading:
Prof. Dang did a survey in the beginning on how we want to be assessed. There were two options for grading:

Option 1:
Midterm exam: 30%
Final exam: 30%
Presentation: 40%

Option 2:
Midterm exam: 30%
Final exam: 30%
Assignments: 40%

For option 2, you choose 2 out of 5 assignments. If you do more than 2, your best scores would be counted. Assignments include seminar reports, literature review and other tasks.

The exams are pretty easy even if you do not know all of the content. Question formats are True/False, MCQ and short answer questions. They also include questions for bonus marks.

My scores:
Midterm: 92/100 (Mean: 87)
Final: Not released
Assignment 1: 18/20 (Mean: 17.4)
Seminar report 2: 19/20 (Mean: ~17 I think)
Overall grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is extremely light. Don't bother studying everything for the exams, you will be fine even with surface level knowledge, but make sure to know your amino acids well.

Since you can choose which assignment you do, just do them when you have less work in other courses. I finished both my assignments within less than two days. You have two weeks to finish them, and can even request an extension.

I took this course in second year and this was my best course grade that sem. If you have even just a bit more knowledge than me before taking this course, you can probably get away with doing even less work than me.

reviews.author: Weewee
reviews.comment_content:
Review of Biochemistry I
Chemical Modification of Proteins
Post Translational Modifications
Protein Purification Techniques
Protein Characterization Techniques
Protein Quantification Techniques
X-ray Crystallography
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance
Cyro-Electron Microscopy
Tools for Determining Protein Structure and Function
Protein Structure Prediction
Proteins and Diseases

There is an optional workshop for learning how to use CyroSPARC and USCF Chimera, and some random guest talks.

The topics taught sound fun and interesting, and are supposed to be fun and interesting, but are not. The scope is often too broad, and not enough detail is covered for certain techniques or reactions. Most of the time, some equations or abstract concepts are introduced and are either not elaborated enough, or can't be elaborated enough due to the lack of knowledge in physics and mathematics. If the content is more condensed and focused on some key points, instead of touching everything briefly, this course would've been very good and interesting for those interested in proteins.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Dang tries to make things interesting, but he teaches quite slowly, with his mainlander accent making it hard to follow. However, he is very responsive to emails, and it is recommended that you email him whenever you don't understand some concepts. He is a good person, but not a good teacher.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since the content is so broad, you don't really know what to study to prepare for exams. At the beginning of the course, the professor asked us what work do we want to do (assignment, report, project, presentation, or exams). In the end, we had to do 2 out of 3 assignments, or do a seminar report and 1 assignment, and have mid-term and final exam.

Assignment 1: 18/20 (mean: 17.4)
Assignment 2: 19/20 (mean: 18)
Assignment 3: didn't do
Seminar Report: didn't do
Mid-term: 85/100 (mean: 87)
Final: don't know yet

This review is written before I got my grades
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light, just do 2 out of 3 assignments. Giving up on mid-term and finals since you have no idea what to study for makes the workload even lighter.

reviews.author: bich jj
reviews.title: Not recommended if you managed to skip LIFS 3010
reviews.comment_content:
Kinase, domain, motif, how to play with yeast, residue interaction. Useful if you want to do research.

Liang Chun focuses more on how to apply knowledge, like extension of LIFS 3010. Many experimental skills. Around 20 chapters for his part, including DNA replication, transcription, translation, yeast as experiment model, ways to test protein-protein interaction, protein-DNA interaction, ubiquitination)

Zhang Mingjie focuses more on chemical interaction between protein domains. Fewer but lengthier topics
reviews.comment_teaching:
Liang Chun teaches super fast and he expects you already studied his LIFS3010 beforehand. Better revise 3010 first if you want to get a good grade.
Zhang Mingjie teaches slower and can learn something if you try to ask or answer his question. He is like secondary school teacher somehow.
There were lecture videos :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Try your best in Liang Chun's part. Memorize as much as you can. His exam is like 3010. He also gave an essay like doing abstract after reading his given paper. Quiz may be given to check understanding.

Zhang Mingjie will slaughter you. His exam was very long and difficult. Requires sense in doing experiement or you won't be able to answer his questions.
reviews.comment_workload: Only one essay during Liang Chun's part.
